displayed_text: Patient: I’m so - I’ve seen it. I’ve seen it… Doctor: Okay. Yeah, this’ll be… Patient: …and I’ve had it so if that makes more sense for you… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …go for it. Doctor: Thank you. I think you know when you have stuff in the in the belly though we don’t like to open you up unless we have to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because it will create more scarring and that’s a different thing than the prostate. Patient: I had none from that da Vinci procedure. Doctor: We will, we will get in, we will get out with these samples, done. Now you know anytime we poke there’s always a downside because you’re poking… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …bleeding, infection, you could pop something, uh admission, any of the above. So… Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. I don’t have to be a rabbit anymore? We might have to change this little tail that I’m growing. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He lost seven pounds in a week. (Laughter) Doctor: It’s really key. Don’t let people take your money for crazy stuff. Patient: Right, okay. Family Member: We’re just afraid, to be honest with you, is like you know we feel a little helpless here this conversation with you, but I think what we’re trying to do is like figure out ____ like what can I do to like to cause it to get worse. Doctor: Stay thin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him?

Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right?

Family Member: Yeah. I saw that this morning. Doctor: Oh, my. Family Member: North and south was shut down. Doctor: Oh, boy. Patient: No south of us Doctor: Yeah. It was police incident. I’m not sure exactly what they say it was but- Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing.

Patient: So that, so that’ll cover that. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Do I still get the prune juice and all that shit or not? Doctor: If you – well, you may not need it. Patient: I may not need it. Okay. Okay. So, we’ll just try the pills first. Doctor: Yes. And then you keep goin’ with your pain medicine – Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way.

Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan.

Patient: Right. Doctor: This tells you, you know, you can read the consent. We’ll review your records to see if you’re eligible. Otherwise, we can start the chemo in a few weeks. Stop the abiraterone now. Continue on the prednisone. It says stop the abiraterone, and it tells you on this page that I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then it says that, huh, I refilled your ibuprofen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All righty. Thanks doc. Doctor: You hang in there. Hope we get you out of pain soon. Patient: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Uh-huh.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay.

Patient: There’s uh, okay, is there any other; that was a surprise that it was larger, or that it was even there…there was a marker. Doctor: I know, yeah, the measurement totally did not indicate that. Patient: And why- Doctor: That was a shock. No, I agree with you. Patient: and that’s why – I don’t – that’s what I was trying to get at. It wasn’t there. Doctor: Yes, the reading was completely different from what actually was; you know that’s the problem, that the person reading is not the one doing the CRYO, in this case. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. So he’s the only one who would read them (papers shuffling) Patient: To see what happens, what’s going on. Doctor: Yeah, because the report - Healthcare Professional: It could switch; the report doesn’t say it helped. It didn’t say it was Doctor: No, I agree. Family Member: And to report that you got back.

Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel –

Family Member: everyone gets chemo. Which is great for me, you’re like wow, I guess it’s great for you but you know we all have mixed feelings a little bit. I get that. Patient: Right. Doctor: The second study is chemotherapy plus an immunotherapy versus chemotherapy. So, docetaxel plus immunotherapy versus docetaxel. So, you know, either one of those is doable. Again, if you had stuff outside of bone that’s probably what we should do. Hi, oh, for the opioids, Okay, for your pain, yeah. So, then the other part is what if you’re just bone. So, let’s say we do this and you’re just in your bones, no lymph nodes, liver, nothing, it’s clean then I think we should consider radium or Xofigo. Family Member: Together with the docetaxel? Doctor: No, just radium. So, there it’s um to combine with anything else is not standard of care and we don’t have our trial up yet with radium plus something. But, at this moment standard of care is just monthly radium for six months and that improves your survival span. So does chemotherapy but radium you can only give if it’s just in bone. So, if you have it like in the liver or whatever kind of like when we first started Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.::: strongly disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind::: strongly disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Oh my gosh what uh what uh… Family Member: At the G__ Doctor: What do you do? Family Member: Dosimetrist. Doctor: Oh wow. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Wow! Small world. Maybe my husband was in training in radiation oncology. Maybe you know him. Family Member: I think so. Doctor: Yeah because (laughs) Patient: Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: You know that was twenty some years ago so that’s probably about right. Family Member: That is.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Okay? Okay, let me see if she’s around so I can just give you a time frame um and uh thanks for bringing this in. This is very helpful. Patient: Good. Um hum. Family Member: We were happy when the results came in. Doctor: Yeah, no genes . Okay, great, good to see you. Family Member: Okay, thanks. Doctor: Happy holiday if I don’t see you before then. Patient: Happy holiday to you.

Family Member: No. Patient: Oh about two thousand twelve. No, I didn’t even have it then. It wasn’t even bad as this. No that’s why Dr. G took it under advisement. Doctor: And has it gotten worse? Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, it’s gotten worse. I’m trying to think what; I had a CAT scan that’s what it was of both my lungs last week. Doctor: What did they tell you about that? Patient: They didn’t tell me anything about it yet. I see Dr. G___ next week. Doctor: And you’re still taking the Enzalutamide? Patient: What’s that? Doctor: The Xtandi. Patient: Yes, I am, yes. Four pills a day. Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I feel pretty good.
